articles.title: Nine out of 10 Aussies admit to distracted driving
articles.summary: A further 30 per cent of Australians don't care about the road rules, according to a survey.    -      in a stunning survey by Aussies for Road Safety.  - i.e. they do not care about road rules.

articles.title: Nine out of 10 Aussies admit to distracted driving
articles.summary: A further 30 per cent of Australians don't care about the road rules, according to a survey.    -      in a stunning survey by Aussies for Road Safety.  - i.e. they do not care about road rules.

articles.title: From Crisis To Cooperation: Why US–Pakistan Climate Collaboration Is A Strategic Imperative
articles.author: Asad Ali
articles.summary: Pakistan is among the top ten most vulnerable countries to climate change. Pakistan contributes less than 1% to global emissions. Pakistan is emerging as a significant player in renewable energy and has expanded its renewable output by nearly 50%. The US has cutting-edge capabilities in these sectors and should share them with Pakistan to build climate resilience from the ground up.

articles.title: Nine out of 10 Aussies admit to distracted driving
articles.summary: Nine out of 10 Aussies admit to distracted driving. A further 30 per cent say they don't care about the road rules, according to a survey by the Australian National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (ANSTS).       .

articles.title: PM meets with the King
articles.summary: Nine out of 10 Aussies admit to distracted driving. A further 30 per cent say they don't care about the road rules, according to a survey by the Australian National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (ANSTS).       .

articles.title: Scientists issue warning about crisis unfolding along US coastlines: 'Going to get worse in the future'
articles.author: Cody Januszko
articles.summary: According to Yale Climate Connections, areas along the U.S. coastlines are experiencing severe flooding more than other regions due to climate change. Virginia Institute of Marine Science developed a Sea Level Report Card for 36 communities in the United States. The data revealed uneven sea-level rise across the country. In Grand Isle, Louisiana, the sea level is rising at a rate of 8.24mm (~0.324 inches) per year, while in Seattle it's rising at rate of 2.13mm per year.

articles.title: Officials stress disaster preparedness as threats loom in the Atlantic
articles.summary: Wake Co. officials are ramping up efforts to prepare for hurricane season. National Preparedness Month is during which Wake County officials are focusing on hurricane preparedness.      Â   "The Atlantic hurricane season is underway and Wake County is preparing.

articles.title: Ice Floe Disintegration: Accelerated Breakdown Study
articles.author: Sophie Lin
articles.summary: Every second, 280 billion tons of ice are lost from the Earth's glaciers and ice sheets. Coastal communities are already experiencing increased flooding, erosion, and saltwater intrusion into freshwater sources due to climate change. The West Antarctic Ice Sheet is particularly vulnerable due to its unique geological structure.

articles.title: Western Visayas: Opong leaves P43.7M infra, P1.7M agri damage
articles.author: dbongcac
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Opong left an estimated P43.7 million in infrastructure damage and P1 million in agricultural losses across Western Visayas. At least 162 metric tons of crops were destroyed, while five bridges and flood control structures sustained damage. Iloilo province suffered the heaviest farm losses at P1.4 million or 141.5 metric tons, followed by Guimaras with P231,836 or 19.4 metric tons and Antique with P19,464 or 1.3 metric tons. More than 116 hectares of farmland were affected.

articles.title: 'So much harder': extreme heat, care work and the city
articles.summary: There is a 444% increase for heat-related deaths in Sydney under 3C of warming. Western Sydney is the epicentre of the heat problem, with summer temperatures approaching 50C on occasion and suburbs under-served in terms of cooling green spaces, sheltered bus stops and comfortable homes. Social researcher Rebecca Huntley says Australians often underestimate how hot parts of the country can get.

articles.title: 'So much harder': extreme heat, care work and the city
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: They are already the deadliest natural disaster in the country. The national climate risk assessment projects a 444 per cent increase for heat-related deaths in Sydney under 3C of warming, which is expected to rise further in the future. The death toll is already the highest in Australia.

articles.title: 'So much harder': extreme heat, care work and the city
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: As global temperatures rise, heatwaves are becoming more frequent and severe. There is a 444% increase for heat-related deaths in Sydney under 3C of warming. Western Sydney is the epicentre of the heat problem, with summer temperatures approaching 50C on occasion and suburbs under-served in terms of cooling green spaces, sheltered bus stops and comfortable homes.

articles.title: Charlotte urged to stay alert to possible Hurricane Imelda in the tropics
articles.author: The Charlotte Observer
articles.summary: There is a risk of heavy rains and flash flooding in the Carolinas on Friday, the National Hurricane Center says.       in the hurricane center's forecast for Friday is a tropical storm with hurricane-force winds and heavy rains, but no specific tropical cyclones.

articles.title: Humberto is now a hurricane & expected to strengthen. Latest forecast for NC
articles.author: The Charlotte Observer
articles.summary: There is uncertainty in long-term forecasts. North Carolinians should monitor the tropics in coming days, as well. The forecast is not very accurate.       .   in the short-term. The long- term forecast is more accurate.

articles.title: Australia unearths gigantic iron ore deposit in Hamersley
articles.summary: Australia has discovered a huge iron ore deposit in Hamersley. The deposit is estimated to contain 55 billion metric tons of high-grade iron ore valued at over $5.7 trillion. The origin of the deposit dates back 1.4 billion years when the Columbia or 'Nuna' supercontinent broke up, resulting in a tectonic upheaval. The current geological models state that the richest iron ore deposits on Earth were formed around 2.2 to 2.0 billion years ago. However, a new study by geologists from the University of Colorado and University of Western Australia has challenged the existing theory. The main ore-forming event occurred 1 billion years later than previously estimated.

articles.title: Himachal Apple Farmers Face Severe Crop Losses Demand Govt Action
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: Heavy rains, hailstorms and downpours have damaged apple crops, while leaf drop disease has further exacerbated the problem. The poor road conditions have caused delays in transportation, resulting in some apples reaching the market late and reducing their value. Anil Deshta, an apple farmer from Shimla, has seen his crops completely destroyed due to heavy rainfall. He hasn't been able to fetch a good price for his apples and the production costs haven't been covered.

articles.title: 12 million birds predicted to migrate across Pennsylvania Sunday night
articles.author: Leah Zerbe
articles.summary: Millions of migrating birds are flying across Pennsylvania this week. BirdCast uses data and technology to create real-time bird migration forecasts and maps. People should turn off outdoor lights between the hours of 11 p.m. and 6 a.m., close blinds and curtains, plant native trees and shrubs, and stop using rat poisons.

articles.title: B.C. climate news: Report finds Canada's 2030 emissions targets out of reach  Hundreds of houses evacuated because of wildfire in Peachland
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: Emily Lowan, 25, was voted in as new leader of B.C. Greens. Munro Lake fire forces hundreds of evacuations near Peachland. Canada's 2030 emissions target is out of reach after progress stalled in 2024. Human activities like burning fossil fuels and farming livestock are main drivers of climate change.

articles.title: B.C. climate news: Report finds Canada's 2030 emissions targets out of reach  Hundreds of houses evacuated because of wildfire in Peachland
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: The Earth is 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s. The past 10 years are the 10 warmest on record. Human activities have raised atmospheric CO2 by nearly 49% since 1850. The world is not on track to meet the Paris Agreement target to keep global temperature from exceeding 1.5 C.

articles.title: B.C. climate news: Report finds Canada's 2030 emissions targets out of reach  Hundreds of houses evacuated because of wildfire in Peachland
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: Emily Lowan, a 25-year-old climate activist, was voted in as new leader of B.C. Greens. Munro Lake fire forces hundreds of evacuations near Peachland. Human activities have raised the atmosphere's carbon dioxide content by 50 per cent in less than 200 years.

articles.title: Easy recipe: Golden chicken roast
articles.author: Chef Ali Mandhry
articles.summary: Easy recipe for golden chicken roast is based on salt and white vinegar. Roast the chicken in an oven at 180°C for one hour and flip it after 30 minutes if you have an air fryer. Enjoy with some roasted crushed potatoes and a side of sour milk raita.

articles.title: N.C. Department of Natural and Cultural Resources looks back
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated the mountains of western North Carolina a year ago. The storm forced the closure of all 18 of the N.C. Department of Natural and Cultural Resources' sites. Some of the sites were closed for nearly a year.

articles.title: Humberto's Wrath: Southeast US Braces for Hurricane Impact
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Atlantic Ocean is brewing severe weather as Hurricane Humberto advances. A parallel weather system poses an imminent threat to the Southeast US. Charleston's Mayor, William Cogswell, enacted a state of emergency. The Bahamas is bracing for heavy rainfall and potential tropical storm impacts. South Florida remains vigilant.

articles.title: Ghana champions locally led climate adaptation at UNGA80
articles.summary: Seidu Issifu is the Minister of State for Climate Change and Sustainability in Ghana. He was at the UNGA80 Global Center on Adaptation Leaders' Dialogue on the theme 'Shaping Resilient Futures', held during the 80th Session of the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA80). He represented the President of Ghana, John Dramani Mahama. The Dialogue was co-chaired by HE Macky Sall, 4th President of Senegal and Chair of the GCA Board, and HE Åsmund Aukrust, Minister for International Development of Norway.

articles.title: Philippines Floods: 11 Dead, Storm Bualoi Heads to Vietnam
articles.summary: Eleven people died and 400,000 people were displaced in the Philippines due to Tropical Storm Bualoi and Super Typhoon Ragasa. The increasing frequency and intensity of these storms, coupled with systemic failures in infrastructure and governance, are creating a dangerous feedback loop. The future will demand a proactive, holistic approach that integrates climate adaptation, good governance and community resilience.

articles.title: 19 dead, 2.1M affected by typhoons, southwest monsoon
articles.author: Franco Jose C. Baroña
articles.summary: Mirasol, Nando and Opong are the combined effects of the southwest monsoon and three tropical cyclones that have left at least 19 people dead, 18 injured and 14 missing. 2,171,964 people have been affected across 14 regions. Flooding, landslides, storm surges, and maritime incidents were reported in at least 14 regions, with a total of 590 incidents recorded nationwide. The damage to agriculture is estimated at P914.9 million, with over 31,000 farmers and fishermen affected and more than 78,000 metric tons of crops lost. At least 5,282 houses were reported damaged, 726 of which were totally destroyed. 165 flights

articles.title: Philippines is the world's most disaster-prone country: Now what?
articles.author: Manila Bulletin
articles.summary: Philippines tops the World Risk Index 2025. The archipelagic geography, exposure to an average of 20 typhoons a year, and increasing climate volatility make the country vulnerable to natural disasters. The government and private sectors have established many initiatives to reduce, and mitigate, the severe effects of natural disasters, but they need to be paired with structural reforms.

articles.title: Heavy rains leave 602,666 users without drinking water.
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Heavy rains yesterday left 511 homes affected, 2,555 people displaced, 11 communities cut off, three roads damaged, and an equal number of bridges damaged. 32 aqueducts were affected, 31 of which are out of service, affecting approximately 602,666 users. COE issued an alert for 30 provinces due to the potential for flooding in rivers, streams, and ravines. Azua, San José de Ocoa, San Cristóbal, Santo Domingo, and the National District are on red alert. La Vega, María Trinidad Sánchez, Monseñor Nouel, Pedernales, San Juan, Barahona

articles.title: Hurricane Humberto & potential Tropical Storm Imelda moving closer to SC. Latest forecast
articles.author: The Sun News
articles.summary: Unnamed disturbance could be a bigger threat to South Carolina than Hurricane Humberto in the Atlantic. It's currently brewing in the ocean.   It's not officially a hurricane yet. It is a disturbance.  It is currently in the middle of the sea.

articles.title: 2025 Arctic Sea Ice Minimum Nearly Half A Million Square Kilometers More Than 2007
articles.author: P Gosselin
articles.summary: In the late 2000s, experts and climate bedwetters, like Al Gore, warned the late summer Arctic sea ice would disappear already by 2015. The alarmists were wrong. Arctic lat summer sea ice trend has been flat for nearly 2 decades, defying the global warming trend prediction.

articles.title: So about those non-hurricanes...
articles.author: John Robson
articles.summary: There is no evidence of an increase in the frequency and ferocity of hurricanes. Matthew Wielicki has been monitoring the Colorado State University's real-time hurricane dashboard and it's not showing any increase in this area at all. He's monitoring it because he's concerned about climate change.

articles.title: Kildare's hedgerows are under threat because of the amount of new construction taking place
articles.author: Paul O'Meara
articles.summary: Cllr Rupert Heather wants Kildare County Council to protect the county's hedgerows. He's particularly concerned about those bordering new developments across the county. He says it's necessary to "help conserve our natural environment."

articles.title: Study finds many homes overheating in summer
articles.author: Alexia Kalaitzi
articles.summary: Greenpeace and the Hellenic Passive House Institute monitored 29 residences across seven Greek cities between July 15 and August 31. Many Greek homes are overheating in summer with the higher temperatures, recording indoor temperatures that in some cases exceeded 34 degrees Celsius. High humidity and carbon dioxide levels worsened living conditions.

articles.title: Heavy rain hits Kalyana Karnataka, Kalaburagi schools closed
articles.author: Uniindia News Service
articles.summary: Heavy rainfall battered the Kalyana Karnataka region, including Kalaburagi, Bidar and Yadgir, causing widespread damage to crops, roads, and other infrastructure. The district administration has declared holidays for schools today and tomorrow as a precautionary measure. More than 10 kilometers of state highway have been damaged. Member of Parliament Radhakrishna Doddamani announced that 2,500 food kits would be distributed to families affected by the heavy rains.

articles.title: Central localities on high alert as typhoon Bualoi moves closer
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi is forecast to make landfall over Nghe An, Ha Tinh, and Quang Tri provinces on the morning of September 28. It is expected to bring heavy rains, heavy winds, flooding, flashfloods, landslides, and coastal inundation. The Ministry of Agriculture and Environment has issued an urgent directive to call fishing vessels back to shore or steer them out of the storm's path. Military Region 5 has placed its units on combat readiness, deploying 29,000 officers and soldiers who are prepared to mobilise immediately upon orders.

articles.title: PHOTOS: Hurricane Helene then and now
articles.author: Moss Brennan
articles.summary: One year after Hurricane Helene, photos show how far we've come since then. Do you have photos showing how far the community has come since Helene hit? If so, send them to editor@wataugademocrat.com and they can be shared with the rest of the world.

articles.title: Seattle Mayor Bruce Harrell and City Leaders Condemn EPA's Proposed Repeal of Climate Regulations Amid Local Impact Concerns
articles.author: Brian Cook
articles.summary: Seattle officials have submitted public comments opposing the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's proposal to repeal key climate regulations affecting greenhouse gas (GHG) emission standards for motor vehicles. Mayor Bruce Harrell emphasized that GHG emissions and resulting climate change are already affecting Seattle through extreme heat, wildfire risks, flooding, rising sea levels and loss of snowpack and glaciers.

articles.title: Letter: Trump's wealth shields him from the effects of climate change. We don't have that luxury.
articles.author: James Allred
articles.summary: In his recent speech to the U.N., President Trump again claimed that global warming/climate change are a hoax and a 'con job'. He doesn't believe the scientific data showing that as more CO2 accumulates in the atmosphere, more heat is radiated back to Earth. Trump is very wealthy and he can use his wealth to shield his grandchildren from the potential effects of a warming planet.

articles.title: Horry Co. initiates emergency plans as officials monitor tropical weather
articles.author: Juliet Colville
articles.summary: Horry County Emergency Management Department moved to Level 2 Operation Condition (OPCON 2) on Saturday to prepare for potential tropical threats. Emergency Management is discussing with the South Carolina Emergency Management Division and coastal communities. The Emergency Operations Center is not currently activated, but emergency management is monitoring the situation closely.

articles.title: Bay of Bengal's Low Pressure Threatens Durga Puja Festivities
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: A new low-pressure area forming in the Bay of Bengal threatens to dampen the Durga Puja festivities across South Bengal. IMD has advised fishermen against venturing into the sea near the West Bengal-Odisha coast, as rough sea conditions are expected.

articles.title: What is climate justice without the voices of indigenous women with disabilities?
articles.summary: Caroline Kinkuhaire is the Gender and Advocacy Officer at Youth For Green Communities. According to UN report, women with disabilities are disproportionately affected by a combination of social, economic and health factors that amplify their risks during disasters and environmental changes. They are often left out of climate adaptation planning and decision-making, stigmatization and marginalization place them at greater disadvantage during emergencies.

articles.title: Bill Ritter: While the president denies climate change, Colorado lives the crisis and leads the response
articles.author: Bill Ritter Jr.
articles.summary: This week in New York City, Governor Bill Ritter moderated a panel at Climate Week. He believes that climate change is an undeniable reality that we can see, measure and feel. Clean energy transition is not just a moral imperative, it is a business case. Colorado is a leader in renewable energy and climate innovation.

articles.title: Letters From Readers, Sept. 27, 2025
articles.summary: In July, a report to the Secretary of Energy, Christopher Wright, was completed by The Climate Working Group, an assembly of five distinguished scientists, all Ph.Ds commissioned to assess the claims of man-caused climate change. The report states that climate change is exaggerated.

articles.title: N.C National Forests continues recovery after Hurricane Helene
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Forest Service has made significant progress in repairing and restoring the Pisgah and Nantahala national forests from the destruction caused by Hurricane Helene one year ago. 'Hurricane Helene had an unprecedented impact across all of western North Carolina and the damage on the national forests was particularly profound.

articles.title: Fresh Low-Pressure System Likely Over Bay of Bengal on October 1
articles.author: Itishree Sethy
articles.summary: A new low-pressure system is expected to form over the northern and central Bay of Bengal around October 1. It could bring heavy rainfall to coastal Odisha, West Bengal, and parts of Andhra Pradesh during Durga Puja celebrations. Fishermen have been warned not to go into the Bay due to squally winds.

articles.title: One year since Hurricane Helene, here are 6 stories of destruction, heroism, strength
articles.author: Chrissy Murphy
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit western North Carolina on Sept. 27, 2024. One year later, stories of the storm's devastation poured out from our communities. People lost their homes, their farms, their businesses and their lives. People came together to recover after the storm.

articles.title: Mega JACKPOT for THIS country as it discovers treasure worth $5700000000000! It the world's largest..., scientists stunned due...
articles.author: support@india.com
articles.summary: Australia has unearthed a huge iron ore deposit in Hamersley, which is being touted as largest iron ore reserve on the planet. The deposit is estimated to contain 55 billion metric tons of high-grade iron ore, valued at over USD 5.7 trillion. The origin of the deposit dates back 1.4 billion years when the Columbia or 'Nuna' supercontinent broke up. The mineralization likely occurred due to tectonic collisions during the realignment of continents.

articles.title: 7 News Belize
articles.summary: PM of Belize urges the G20 responsible for 80% of emissions to commit to more ambitious emission reduction targets. Developed nations and development banks must lead the mobilization of $1.3 trillion in climate finance and prioritize SIDs whose adaptation and loss and damage needs are most urgent.

articles.title: UK households urged to leave out one food item for robins in autumn
articles.summary: Gardeners are encouraged to provide a specific type of food for robins during the autumn and winter months. Robins do not migrate south for the winter, so gardeners need to take care of them all year round. Ark Wildlife recommends leaving out suet pellets, fat balls, fruits and berries, mealworms and calcium worms.

articles.title: See photos from Statesville's Hurricane Helene relief efforts in 2024
articles.author: Ben Gibson
articles.summary: Volunteers organize relief efforts after Hurricane Helene at the Statesville Regional Airport in the wake of the hurricane in 2024. Tommy Wingler of Wingler Farms helps to unload hay that will be taken to help other farmers recover in the aftermath of the storm.

articles.title: See photos from Statesville's Hurricane Helene relief efforts in 2024
articles.author: Ben Gibson
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit western North Carolina in late September 2024. Volunteers worked to airlift supplies for 10 days out of the Statesville Regional Airport before ground delieveries could be made to avoid the damage caused by Helene's hurricane force winds and storm surge.

articles.title: Birdwatchers, fall 2025 bird migration is record-setting. See maps, birds migrating now
articles.author: USA TODAY NETWORK
articles.summary: Birds are on the move for their annual fall migration. Most of the migration is concentrated in the central U.S., with Ohio being one of the main hot spots. Radar estimates suggest more than 1.2 billion birds took to the skies on Sept. 25. In Rhode Island, the bird migration isn't as dense.

articles.title: Can an AI-Guided Robot Help a California City Resist Sea Level Rise and Sequester Carbon?
articles.author: Jennifer Ugwa
articles.summary: By 2050, sea levels in California are projected to rise between 6 and 14.5 inches above the average of levels recorded in the last quarter of the past century. Sea levels in San Rafael, in Marin County, could rise by over 17 inches in the next 25 years. In 2023, the state of California enacted the Regional Shoreline Adaptation Plans (RSAP) to address sea level rise, build coastal resilience and support communities near the water. The initiative gave rise to the Sea Level Rise Collaborative Project (SLRCP) in the city of San Rafael.

articles.title: Unpacking Trump's ‘Con Job' Comments About Climate Change to the UN
articles.author: Jenni Doering
articles.summary: Jenni Doering and Aynsley O'Neill discuss President Donald Trump's speech to the U.N. General Assembly on climate change and renewable energy. The last 10 years were the 10 hottest on record and 2024 tops the list with a departure from the pre-industrial average of 1.5 degrees Celsius. California Gov. Gavin Newsom, who lives in one of the most crisis-prone states in America, reminded the audience of the high stakes.

articles.title: Feathered Friends: Reflecting on autumn beauty and the birds
articles.author: Hans Kunze
articles.summary: It's September 12th and the weather has been fantastic. September is a transition time for bird populations as many species of birds have already left for the South and several birds from Canada are passing through. Many birds will linger well into fall. It's possible for sighting unusual birds in locations that may not seem normal.

articles.title: One year after Hurricane Helene -- how it reshaped many people's perspectives
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene has changed people's thinking about being prepared for the next disaster. KDLG 670 AM is currently playing on AM 670. FM 89.9 is playing on FM 89,9.    For more information, visit NPR.org.

articles.title: ‘An absolute shocker': Greta Thunberg's flotilla hit with drones and ABBA music
articles.summary: Drones attacked Greta Thunberg's flotilla's boats south of Greece. Communication radios jammed, playing ABBA music instead of the usual radio signals.   Danica De Giorgio had to give her winner this week to Greta's Flotilla.

articles.title: Government releases climate risk assessment report
articles.author: Daily News Reporter
articles.summary: The President's Office – Regional Administration and Local Government has launched the National Climate Risk and Vulnerability Assessment Report. The report is aimed at identifying areas most at risk of climate change and informing strategic resilience planning across Tanzania. The assessment was conducted by the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF) through its Local Climate Adaptive Living Facility (LoCAL) programme in collaboration with EU, Norway, Belgium and Ireland.

articles.title: Is hurricane season in Los Cabos getting longer?
articles.author: Chris Sands
articles.summary: By the year 2100, the hurricane season in Los Cabos will have stretched beyond its traditional close at the end of November into early December. The number of named storms in the Eastern Pacific region will decrease slightly on an annual basis moving forward. There will be fewer storms but they will be stronger.

articles.title: THE ENVIRONMENT: Is It Time for Brevard County to Reevaluate Mangrove Policy?
articles.author: Space Coast Daily
articles.summary: Mangroves are coastal plants that function in preventing shoreline erosion, filtering water, and providing a nursery for wildlife. The FLDEP enacted the Mangrove Trimming and Preservation Act in 1996 as part of lagoon preservation. Higher annual water temperatures and rise in sea level have aided in mangrove habitat expansion.

articles.title: Climate change could slash global GDP by 24% by the year 2100
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Global per capita incomes could decline by as much as 24% by the year 2100 due to climate change. Lower-income nations, already struggling against extreme weather events with limited infrastructure, could suffer losses 30-60% higher than the global average. Sectors from agriculture to manufacturing, transport, and retail are expected to suffer.

articles.title: Yorkshire Wildlife Trust issues warning on climate change
articles.author: Francis Redwood
articles.summary: The Wildlife Trusts published their assessment of the impact of climate change on UK species and habitats. According to the report, changing weather patterns have severely affected wildlife, with drought and heat extremes drying out woodlands and wetlands on Yorkshire Wildlife Trust nature reserves. The trust is undertaking several initiatives to protect the natural environment, including river restoration and habitat restoration in the Yorkshire Dales.

articles.title: Letter: Remember one man's drain is another man's flood
articles.author: Patrick Adams
articles.summary: There is an increasing risk of flooding in the Severn Valley due to climate change. Farming is the worst affected by climate change, so food prices are rising faster than most other things. The wealthy can move to higher ground and bulk buy food supplies, but the rest of us can't. We need to adapt to the changing climate and stop things getting worse.

articles.title: UK alum helps build ‘one-of-a-kind' temporary water pretreatment system after Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Christopher Carney University
articles.summary: On Sept. 27, 2024, Hurricane Helene devastated North Carolina and the Western Appalachian region of the country, resulting in more than 100 reported deaths. Flooding and landslides caused damage to the primary and secondary water systems, leaving thousands without power, transportation, communications and clean water.

articles.title: Wide Swings of Warming and Cooling
articles.author: John Leake
articles.summary: There is a lot of talk about 'record heat' in Texas, which is attributed to global warming caused by human activity. The hottest maximum temperature ever recorded in Texas occurred twice: First on August 12, 1936, in Seymour, northwest of Dallas, and again on June 28, 1994, in Monahans, a city near Odessa. According to NOAA records, the hottest summer in Texas history was 1980. In Dallas/Fort Worth, Texas, high temperatures exceeded 100 °F (38 °C) a total of 69 times, including a record 42 consecutive days from June 23 to August 3.

articles.title: SC: MIDLANDS BRACE FOR HUMBERTO AND OTHER STORMS
articles.summary: South Carolina prepares as Hurricane Humberto and soon-to-be Imelda threaten the region, and so does South Carolina's coastline.  Copyright 2025 by KOAM News Now. All rights reserved. No part of this material may be reproduced, republished, rewritten or retransmitted.

articles.title: Australia court fines man over $200,000 for deepfake porn - Jamaica Observer
articles.author: Jamaica Observer
articles.summary: A man in Australia was killed by a bomb in his apartment in Sydney. He was in his mid-30s, according to AFP reports.    in Australia, he was living in Sydney at the time of the attack.  In the U.S., he lived in Melbourne.

articles.title: Researchers discover stunning error in theory about powerful natural phenomenon: 'We were off by 90 degrees'
articles.author: Susan Elizabeth Turek
articles.summary: Researchers from the University of Washington found out that northerly winds are responsible for melting the West Antarctic ice sheet, which could cause global sea levels to rise by as much as 20 feet. The research could help prepare the world for the future and limit the adverse effects of rising global temperatures.

articles.title: Australian bird of the year 2025: craft your own origami bird with this simple guide
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Australian bird of the year is almost here. Build your own origami pigeon with these step-by-step instructions. Australia is host to the Australian Bird of the Year award.       .   for this year's award is for the pigeon.

articles.title: LETTER: How to help birds travel safe
articles.author: Delores Duly
articles.summary: Millions of migratory birds are beginning their journey along the Pacific flyway. They will fly directly over our community on their way between Alaska and South America. Lights from homes, streets and businesses can be a dangerous distraction for birds, causing them to fly off course or drop to a lower elevation.

articles.title: Preparations underway for possible tropical impacts
articles.author: Summer Trolli
articles.summary: Brunswick County, North Carolina is preparing for potential tropical storm Imelda to make its way through the Cape Fear River. Some cities and towns have already started preparing for the impacts of potential severe weather associated with systems moving through the area.

articles.title: NDRRMC: 19 reported dead due to Mirasol, Nando, Opong, Habagat
articles.author: Gma Integrated News
articles.summary: Tropical cyclones Mirasol, Nando, Opong, and the Southwest Monsoon (Habagat) have caused a lot of damage in the Philippines. 19 people have died due to the effects of the cyclones. 2,026,246 individuals or 520,165 families were affected in 15 regions, 57 provinces, 504 cities/municipalities, and 4,219 barangays. The number of displaced persons totalled 351,840 and most of them sought shelter in 1,906 evacuation centers. Some 143 cities and municipalities lost power during the weather disturbances.

articles.title: Climate Emergency
articles.summary: Pakistan is in the midst of a climate emergency. The National Disaster Management Authority has failed to deliver to full capacity. Strengthening the NDMA and building strong rescue, recovery, and drainage systems are national priorities. Mehak Fatima, Islamabad, is calling for the state to declare the emergency.

articles.title: The rare weather phenomenon that could impact Australia's spring and summer forecast
articles.author: Kamilia Palu
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming (SSW) is taking place over the south pole. It's brought the usual -50C temperature to about -15C. Previous SSW events have led to warmer and drier conditions across south-east Australia. The last SSW event occurred in 2019, coinciding with the Black Summer bushfires. Western Tasmania is the one part of Australia that has wetter conditions when SSW happens.

articles.title: The rare weather phenomenon that could impact Australia's spring and summer forecast
articles.author: Kamilia Palu
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming (SSW) is taking place over the south pole. It's brought the usual -50C temperature to about -15C. Previous SSW events have led to warmer and drier conditions across south-east Australia. The last SSW event occurred in 2019, coinciding with the Black Summer bushfires. Western Tasmania is the one part of Australia that has wetter conditions when SSW happens.

articles.title: Dennis C. Miller: Living in the Twilight Zone
articles.summary: Quail, doves, pigeons, blackbirds and sparrows ate crumbs in the backyard without disagreement. Humans killed over one hundred million people in the twentieth century in what we call war. Humans kill each other on a massive scale, deny climate change and destroy the environment.

articles.title: Australian bird of the year 2025: craft your own origami bird with this simple guide
articles.author: Josh Nicholas
articles.summary: Voting for the Australian bird of the year starts on 6 October and the winner will be announced on Thursday 16 October. The bird voting has been running since 2017. Previous winners include the magpie (2017), the black-throated finch (2019), the superb fairywren (2021) and the swift parrot (2023).

articles.title: 'We Are Resilient' Survivors From South Greene To Chuckey Share Experiences
articles.author: The Greeneville Sun
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene flooded a residential neighborhood near the Nolichucky Dam in the South Greene community in Greene County, which was hit hard by flooding from Helene's hurricane.       .   in the area near the dam.

articles.title: Energy Insider Podcast: Australia, China and a big week for V2G
articles.author: Renew Economy
articles.summary: Anna Skarbek from Climateworks Centre talks about Australia's emissions on Australia's behalf.       in the video below. In the video, Anna talks to Climateworks Center on Australia’s emissions.  In the Video, Anna explains the background to the video.

articles.title: UK alum helps build ‘one-of-a-kind' temporary water pretreatment system after Hurricane Helene
articles.author: Kentucky New Era
articles.summary: On Sept. 27, 2024, there will be historic winds and rainfall from Hurricane Helene in Lexington, Kentucky. It will be the first time this has happened in the history of the United States. It is due to be caused by Helene's hurricane force winds.

articles.title: Climate change and the positives of electric vehicles
articles.author: Newsday
articles.summary: Donald Trump's comments to the UN on climate change show a lack of knowledge on what is happening. The planet is close to a tipping point and there are large parts that could be destroyed by climate change in large parts of the Earth. The president should be aware of this.

articles.title: EDITORIAL: Ignore rising seas at our own peril
articles.summary: Rising sea levels from a warmer planet could submerge parts of Florida's coastlines in the next century, including parts of southwest Florida, according to Climate Central's report.       in the future, some areas of Florida could be underwater.

articles.title: CM Mohan Charan Majhi reviews rain situation, puts officials on alert
articles.author: Express News Service
articles.summary: Mohan Charan Majhi has directed officials to be fully prepared to deal with the situation arising out of continuous rains due to a low pressure in the Bay of Bengal. 17 district collectors took part in a high-level meeting at Jharsuguda. Several districts may be affected by heavy rains.

articles.title: Statesville airport was hub for help during hurricane
articles.author: Hickory Record
articles.summary: One year ago, remnants of Hurricane Helene hit North Carolina. Western North Carolina took the brunt of the storm. Iredell County avoided much more than a few downed power lines and trees, but the rest of the state was hit hard.

articles.title: What a China-EU climate deal ould do for the world
articles.author: Gulf-Times
articles.summary: There are two stories about China and climate change. The first is that China leads the world in greenhouse-gas emissions, while the second is that it is developing clean technologies that will allow all countries to decarbonise their economies at a faster rate.

articles.title: Hurricane Humberto rages; Imelda could soon threaten U.S.
articles.author: Pittsburgh Tribune Review
articles.summary: Hurricane forecasters are watching three major risk factors for the upcoming hurricane season. The three risk factors are: weather, weather-related factors and human activity in the ocean and the environment. It's still too early to make a determination on the hurricane's exact path.

articles.title: Scars still visible one year after Hurricane Helene
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene hit western North Carolina hard a year ago. The recovery has been painfully slow. Janet Shamlian reports the situation is still very much the same as before the hurricane hit.       .   for confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: What made Hurricane Helene a historic storm?
articles.author: Ashe Post
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene brought record-breaking rain and wind to the High Country in September 2024. It was Boone's most devastating flood event since 1940. Before that, it happened in 1916 and before that, in 1940 and in 1916, as well. It brought heavy rains and wind.

articles.title: Hurricane Humberto intensifies in the Atlantic
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: Tropical storms and Hurricane Humberto are posing potential threats to the Caribbean and Southeastern U.S., according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC). NHC has issued a hurricane warning for the Caribbean, and a tropical storm warning for North America.
